content.webTitle: Morning Mail: Abbott on Iraq, new Nato strikeforce, and those Jennifer Lawrence pictures

fields.headline: Morning Mail: Abbott on Iraq, new Nato strikeforce, and those Jennifer Lawrence pictures
fields.bodyText: Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday. Iraq Prime Minister Tony Abbott says he has no intention to commit combat troops in Iraq, but told parliament a failure to act “means leaving millions of people exposed to death, forced conversion and ethnic cleansing”. The Greens failed to force a debate on military involvement yesterday, with both major parties arguing deployment should remain a matter for executive government to decide. After the announcement that Australia would help supply weapons to Kurds,Iraq’s ambassador to Australia has called for any weapons to be provided via the central government in Baghdad. The UN will send officials to Iraq to investigate persistent reports of Islamic State ‘atrocities’, but the human rights commissioner said government forces would also be investigated. Ukraine Nato is to create a 4,000-strong “spearhead” high-readiness force with capacity to ‘travel light but strike hard’, to help protect member nations against potential Russian aggression. Kiev claims pro-Russia rebels are making decisive gains against Ukrainian forces because Moscow is providing direct military support to rebels, including from “a Russian tank battalion”. Tony Abbott told parliament Australia would adopt tougher sanctions against Russia, accusing Moscow of “deliberately and now openly violating Ukrainian sovereignty”. Kazakhstan is the latest Russian neighbour to feel Vladimir Putin’s chilly nationalist rhetoric, as he called into question the legitimacy of the post-Soviet state while ordering the Kazakhs to be on their best behaviour. Australian news and politics • The Abbott government is seeking to push a new bill through parliament to repeal the mining tax, but the signature policy still faces possible Senate defeat. • There have been extraordinary allegations of a mafia boss helping fund an influential Labor figure’s local election campaign in Victoria, highlighting the state’s weak corruption-fighting powers. • After disgraced former NSW minister Joe Tripodi admitted his involvement in a smear campaign to unseat fellow Labor MP Jodi McKay, former NSW premier Kristina Keneally said it was “the ultimate act of betrayal”. • The home insulation commission has found the former Rudd government ignored dangers that “ought to have been obvious to any competent administration” and should have done more to protect inexperienced workers. Around the world • The UN is warning of floods, storms and searing heat from Arizona to Zambia within four decades in campaign publicising a UN climate summit. • The controversial six-month dolphin hunting season began in the infamous town of Taiji, but bad weather could delay any killing. • A secret report says police forces ‘marred’ the search for Madeleine McCann as agencies fought to join the investigation. • Russia confirms all five geckos have died on their mission to study weightlessness and sex in space. More from around the internet • Among the most viewed on the Guardian this morning are several stories related to the leaking of nude celebrity photos. Van Badham writes, If you click on Jennifer Lawrence’s naked pictures, you’re perpetuating her abuse. Roxanne Gay writes, The Great Naked Celebrity Photo Leak of 2014 is just the beginning. • Australia will enter a historic partnership with NATO this week, and 200 special forces troops could return to Afghanistan, The Australian reports. • Major players in business are set to fight competition rules proposed by the ACCC that could make them responsible for the financial woes of their rivals, The Financial Review reports. • A banned GP says he will keep supplying medical cannabis to Australian children, despite the threat of legal action, the Herald Sun reports. One last thing A Melbourne man’s life was saved from a raging inferno when his cat jumped on his head and started screaming at him. Have an excellent day – and if you spot anything I’ve missed, let me know in the comments here or on Twitter @earleyedition. Sign up Get the Morning Mail direct to your inbox before 8am every day by signing up here.
